bibl.title: Article: The Experiment with Yellow Fever, by Lena Warner, June 1902

div1.p: Warner's article describes her role in the yellow fever experiments and how to best care for yellow fever patients. An autograph note follows the text and calls the piece a "pure fabrication as to her part."

div1.head: Article: The Experiment with Yellow Fever, by Lena Warner, June 1902
div1.p: THE EXPERIMENT WITH YELLOW FEVER

As our experiment with this disease has played such a prominent part before the
medical world of today, and especially is of vital importance to us of the South, I
shall endeavor to relate something of my contact with the work. I shall allude only
to the practical side, as the scientific and theoretical phases have already been
presented to you by my superior officers.

We fully realize, since our experiment, that the mosquito ranks high in economic
importance; her absence from our environment is most desirable, not only as an ordinary
pest, but since science has proved she is pestilential, and upon her narrow shoulders
is placed the blame of causing, or at least transmitting two of the most widespread
and dangerous diseases of tropical and semi-tropical climates.

In June of 1900, our Government sent to Columbia Barracks, U. S. Army Post,
located at Quemados, Cuba, a board of medical officers for the purpose of pursuing
scientific investigation with reference to the acute contagious diseases, with
special interest in locating Icteroid X, an unknown germ supposed to be the cause of
Yellow Fever. As this disease was prevalent among the soldiers, on July 10 I received
orders from Major Havard to proceed to Columbia Barracks. Here began my first exper-
ience in the detention camp.

In September, Major R. Jefferson Cain telephone me from headquarters, located
at the Palace in Havana, that he had sent three officers and one Sergeant. En route
to our detention camp at Post Columbia, they became ill, so ill they were compelled
to stop at Las Animas, a Civil Hospital located at Havana. As there were no other
Yellow Fever cases at Las Animas or no immune nurses, two immune hospital corps men
were sent to care for the four cases. I called our Hospital Corps Sergeant to ap-
point two corps men for study, as I was going to Las Animas and would take the two
men with me in my ambulance. We remained there three days. Major William A. Gorgas,
A. S. U. S. Army, was Chief of Staff and also Chief Sanitarian of the Island. While
we were far better prepared to care for the four patients than in the detention camp,
they did not recover. The Commission, Dr. Walter Reed, Dr. Jesse W. Lazear, Dr. A.
Agramonte and Dr. James Carroll, laboratory technician, were diligently searching for
the cause of Yellow Fever.

My first knowledge of the mosquito as the cause was passed on to me by Dr.
Carroll, a member of the above-mentioned Commission, while ill. He informed me that
a mosquito bite was the means of his contracting “Yellow Jack”. The record of that
bears testimony: patient delirious, - although he had asked me to stop by the
laboratory on my rounds and drop a small bit of ripe banana in a test tube contain-
ing two mosquitoes, describing minutely just how the cotton was to be so lightly
replaced to prevent their escape; because I had promised - and perhaps a bit curious,
I found the exact location he had described the test bue containing two mosquitoes.
Yes, I fed them.

All of the precautions usually observed to prevent the spread of contagion
was resorted to; all bedding used by the patients was burned. The bonfires and
weird scenes of 1878 in Memphis were vividly recalled; all clothing and bedding
contacted by the patient was burned. In the meantime, the autopsies held by Drs.
-1-
Lazear and Carroll had greatly improved the treatment. It was through autopsy the
cause of black vomit was found and no medicine was given or food. Perhaps I should
give the treatment, as it was by far more effective than any previously attempted.
The patient was kept perfectly quiet, not even allowed to raise his head. Water or
lemonade was offered every hour; as he was usually thirsty it was seldom he was urged;
a light covering was used. Temperature, respiration and pulse were taken every three
hours and when up to 103° a cold high enema was given (saline) and while this did not
reduce temperature, it was quieting. (We had found that sponging or even ice packs
had no effect upon the temperature.)

Every drop of urine was measured and sent twice daily to the laboratory and re-
corded on the nurse's chart. As the temperature climbs the pulse slows down after
the first 24 hours of the attack; the common duct conveying the bile to the small
intestine becomes so clogged with the thickened bile it begins to disseminate through-
out the system and the entire body assumes a pale yellow color, even the whites of the
eyes; thus the bedside chart is the physicians' guide. The vacant stare usually de-
tected in delirium with other fever cases is absent in yellow fever cases.

No food, solid or liquid or of any description, is given until the temperature
drops to normal, which is usually on the 5th or 6th day. Nor does it rise in the
afternoon. Feeding begins with one dram of milk diluted with one dram of water given
every hour the first six hours, then gradually increased with milk and water decreased;
as the milk is increased the hours are lengthened until 1/2 glass is given every three
hours. After the third day, begin with light diet; on the 10th day the patient may
be propped up in bed and then gradually allowed to become a normal human being.

Shortly after Carroll's recovery, Dr. Jessie W. Lazear was stricken, and gave his
life for the cause of Science, as he wanted to make sure of how many days should pass
after the Stegeomia (mosquito) had bitten a yellow fever patient before she became a
carrier. He found it was 8 days. On the 3rd day after he had turned the test tube
containing Mrs. Stegeomia down on the back of his hand, he had a rigor, and sat up
all night writing down and outlining direct information and procedure of what he and
Carroll had found concerning two species of the mosquitos they had found as carriers.
I missed the doctor on my rounds and sent my orderly to see if he was in his quarters;
Forbes returned saying he was ill and in bed and wished to speak to me. We returned
to Dr. Lazear's quarters and found he had a temperature of 101. I suggested the litter
bearers would take him over to the officers' tent, set apart for the Medical Corps.
He asked me to carefully gather up the sheets of paper he had on the table and put
them away as they were valuable and would be needed on his recovery; his request was
complied with. The next day he had a severe hemorrhage of the stomach (Black Vomit)
and died the 4th night of his attack. I passed the papers over to Major Reed the next
day, not knowing the contents. Three days afterward, Reed called up our group and told
us of their contents. It was on this occasion three of the Hospital Corps men volun-
teered to be experimented on. Early in November the Flag was raised and our Detention
Camp was called Camp Lazear, and Major Reed planned a careful and systematic method of
inoculating non-immunes. At first a test was made to prove Yellow Fever was not con-
tagious. Twenty non-immune men and Dr. Cook, 1st Lieutenant of the Medical Department,
volunteered. They were carefully guarded night and day in a long frame building three
weeks. On their cots were placed blankets and sheets that Yellow Fever patients had
died on; coal oil stoves were burned to keep an even temperature of 100° F. The pe-
culiar odor of Yellow Fever caused by the bedding could be detected five yards from
the building.

Fourteen days and nights passed and not one man went down, - then the experiment
with old Mrs. Stegeomia Mosquito began. Several of the men, who were in the contagious
experiment, volunteered for the mosquito test; the entire number experimented on were
97; each man was paid $200.00 for this test. As soon as the non-immune received his
mosquito bite, he was assigned a cot in Camp Lazear Detention Hospital. A record of each
case was kept; temperature and pulse recorded morning, noon and evening. Before the
5th day, each man went down. As soon as we found a rise of temperature of 99°, he was
put to bed. Dr. Wm. A. Gorgas and Dr. Agramonte were called to assume charge of the
cases. They visited each case separately and each diagnosing it Yellow Fever. Not one
case had Black Vomit, because previous treatments proved it could be eliminated. Other
symptoms were identical; prognosis most favorable; the heart, kidneys and stomach are
the chief organs attacked in this disease.

The third test made was by drawing with hypodermic needle one drop of blood from
a person ill with Yellow Fever, and diluting it with one drop of water and injecting
one-half of this mixture in the arm of a non-immune. The same results would follow
as from the mosquito bite: a typical case of Yellow Fever.

I am glad to state not one of those experimented upon died. Some of the 97 were
Americans, some of them were immigrants just arriving on the Island, and three of them
were volunteers from the Hospital Corps.

The Culex Fascitaus Stegeomia was found prevalent on the Island in certain loca-
tions. She is quite timid and rarely bites one. At night she is most active. She
intuitively realizes her eggs will not be fertile unless she draws blood from man or
beast. We reared our own supply in the laboratory and they were harmless with their
bite until we conveyed them to the bedside of a Yellow Fever subject and she had
bitten him. We would carefully return her into the test tube, the same tube we carried
her there in. She does not enjoy a long life; our oldest female lived 90 days, and
during her life she bit six non-immunes and before the 5th day each one of them came
down with the disease. The time lapsing after biting a fever patient before she could
inoculate a non-immune was determined between 8 and 10 days.

In the meantime, Dr. Wm. A. Gorgas, Chief Sanitarian of the Island, had not been
idle by any means. Yes, the little Island was being cleaned up, mosquitoes included.
Many, many thousands of gallons of coal oil were used in localities where mosquitoes
were found to destroy their eggs or larva. Every cot in Columbia Post Hospital was
screened and every patient sent to this Hospital, placed in the Ward with other
patients; though carefully screened off, they proved to have Yellow Fever. The
Supervising Nurse in the Ward was Miss May Rose Holmes of Memphis, Tennessee. She
was a non-immune, as were also the Hospital Corps men, who were her assistants. Not
one of them ever contracted the disease. The Army Engineering Corps had located the
Hospital on rather a high location, and there were no mosquitoes to pester the sick
up there; our only mosquitoes were those we reared in the laboratory.

The adult Cubans living in Havana were immunes; some of the Cubans coming from
different sections of the Island were stricken soon after their arrival. We inferred
this was why Yellow Fever was never declared epidemic in Havana, as only visitors and
foreigners were attacked and, too, it was more prevalent among the lower class.

From March, 1901, to March, 1902, the only cases I saw were those from our own
experiments.

During the summer of 1901, a party of gentlemen appeared in Havana claiming
to have a sure cure; that by some process of injecting a certain fluid they had
patented in the arm of a non-immune, they could not contract Yellow Fever. I was
informed that two people, one man and one woman, let these gentlemen experiment on
them. I did not witness this so-called experiment, as it was held at Las Animas,
a Civil Hospital in Havana. Both victims died. On the first vessel sailing for
New York the two so-called scientists were passengers.

(Read before Shelby County Medical Society June, 1902; en route to
U. S. Army Hospital at presidio, San Francisco, California)
